moves.1. e4 e5 2. d4 exd4 3. c3 dxc3 4. Bc4 cx: The Danish gambit accepted! An opening which I use on a regular basis. Although it gives two extra pawns to black, it is quite difficult for black to defend against whites extremely mobile pieces.
moves.5... Nc6: This is not a standard line as far as I know. My opponent takes the game out of the opening books. I had to use my aggressive instincts to stay put.
moves.6. Nf3 Bb4+ 7. Nc3 Nge7: Perhaps Nf6 followed by the plan of Ne4 is better!
moves.10... Be7 11. Rad1: ...With the idea of pinning the d pawn after my queen moves out of the d-file.
moves.11... d6 12. Qh5: Keeping the queen in close proximity to the black king.
moves.12... Bd7 13. Rfe1: Seeing that I'd have to make up my position before beginning the assault!
moves.13... Qc8: This,in my view, is the first great error of my opoonent. It allows me to attack instantly.
moves.16. f4: maybe h6 might have saved the game.
moves.16... Ng6 17. f5 Ne5 18. Bxe5: Now I destroy the knight which is the last defense of the king against the f-pawns advance!
moves.20. Qh6: Here my opoonent resigned because there is no defense for Qg7#. A good game. This is why I love the Danish gambit!
